article_title: Europe Car Sales Rise 1.1% in Surprise First Gain of 2020
article_text: LISTEN TO ARTICLE 2:49 SHARE THIS ARTICLE Share Tweet Post Email {"contentId":"QI8MVJDWLU6801","position":"brokerboxarticle","dimensions":{"large_desktop":[[120,60]],"small_desktop":[[120,60]],"tablet":[[120,60]]},"strategy":"viewable","positionIncrement":1,"targeting":{"position":"brokerboxarticle1","url":"/news/articles/2020-10-16/europe-car-sales-rise-1-1-in-surprise-first-gain-of-the-year"},"containerId":"brokerboxarticle-jp2zXwc"} Photographer: Andreas Gebert/Bloomberg Photographer: Andreas Gebert/Bloomberg Automakers eked out a surprise sales increase last month in Europe, the first advance this year for a region still struggling with a patchy recovery reliant on government subsidies. New-car registrations rose 1.1% in September, the European Automobile Manufacturers Association said Friday. Sales gained in Italy and Germany -- two of the major countries offering incentives to support electric-vehicle purchases -- and offset still-slumping demand in Spain and France. {"contentId":"QI8MVJDWLU6801","position":"outstream","dimensions":{"large_desktop":[[1,8]],"small_desktop":[[1,8]],"tablet":[[1,8]]},"strategy":"always","type":"Outstream Video Native Ad","targeting":{"position":"outstream","url":"/news/articles/2020-10-16/europe-car-sales-rise-1-1-in-surprise-first-gain-of-the-year"},"containerId":"outstream-video-1-QI8MVJDWLU6801"} {"contentId":"QI8MVJDWLU6801","position":"outstream","dimensions":{"mobile":[[1,8]]},"strategy":"always","type":"Outstream Video Native Ad","targeting":{"position":"outstream","url":"/news/articles/2020-10-16/europe-car-sales-rise-1-1-in-surprise-first-gain-of-the-year"},"containerId":"outstream-video-2-QI8MVJDWLU6801"} Daimler AG, the maker of Mercedes-Benz cars, reported a rebound in third-quarter earnings late Thursday that topped analysts’ estimates, and expressed optimism about the rest of the year. Truck-maker Volvo Group also posted profit well ahead of analysts’ expectations after cutting costs and benefiting from a post-lockdown recovery in road-haulage. {"contentId":"QI8MVJDWLU6801","position":"box","dimensions":{"mobile":[[300,250],[3,3],[1,1],"fluid"]},"type":"Mobile Body Box Ad","positionIncrement":1,"targeting":{"position":"box1","positionIncrement":1,"url":"/news/articles/2020-10-16/europe-car-sales-rise-1-1-in-surprise-first-gain-of-the-year"},"containerId":"box-gKyEbNV"} Daimler shares led a rally that lifted the Stoxx Europe 600 Automobiles & Parts Index by as much as 2.6%. Sales Surprise Europe's car registrations rise for the first time this year Source: European Automobile Manufacturers Association Note: Data are for European Union, European Free Trade Association and the U.K. Keeping the momentum going may be a challenge. Leaders in the U.K., Germany, Italy and France are struggling to cope with record new Covid-19 cases. Targeted strategies to slow the spread of the disease are being used for now before resorting to the kind of broad national lockdowns that decimated car sales earlier this year. {"contentId":"QI8MVJDWLU6801","position":"desktop-in-article1","dimensions":{"large_desktop":[[5,4]],"small_desktop":[[5,4]]},"type":"Desktop in article Native Ad","targeting":{"position":"desktop-in-article1","url":"/news/articles/2020-10-16/europe-car-sales-rise-1-1-in-surprise-first-gain-of-the-year"},"containerId":"desktop-in-article-1-QI8MVJDWLU6801"} “We’d argue consumers don’t share automakers’ revival hopes,” Michael Dean, a Bloomberg Intelligence analyst, said in a note ahead of the industry’s sales report. He expects annual deliveries to decline at least 20% and sees risk that the drop will be worse because of coronavirus-related restriction measures. Related: Daimler posts $3.6 billion profit on sales recovery, cost cuts Europe’s car sales are still down 29% for the year through September. After deliveries cratered in March and April, automakers pared declines the following three months, then suffered a setback in August. Ups and Downs Europe's largest auto markets saw mixed results last month Source: European Automobile Manufacturers Association Germany’s car market expanded last month for the first time this year, as subsidies for battery-powered vehicles more than quadrupled sales of plug-in hybrid and battery-electric models. But while total registrations rose 8.4% there, Spain saw a 13% drop despite also offering incentives toward EVs. {"contentId":"QI8MVJDWLU6801","position":"in-article1","dimensions":{"mobile":[[5,19],[300,250],[3,3],[1,1],"fluid"],"tablet":[[5,11],[728,90],[1,1]]},"type":"In Article Flex Native Ad","positionIncrement":1,"targeting":{"position":"in-article1","positionIncrement":1,"url":"/news/articles/2020-10-16/europe-car-sales-rise-1-1-in-surprise-first-gain-of-the-year"},"containerId":"in-article-1-QI8MVJDWLU6801"} Western Europe was the worst-performing region this year through August for Volkswagen AG, the top-selling automaker both in the region and globally. Still, with a recovery on solid footing in China, Chief Executive Officer Herbert Diess said VW’s monthly orders and deliveries were up as September came to a close. He sees the positive trend continuing into the fourth quarter. “It needs to be seen how much of the currently strong sales momentum is pent-up demand, how much is cyclical and what’s related to ‘the reincarnation of the car,’” Arndt Ellinghorst, Sanford C. Bernstein & Co.’s European auto analyst, wrote in an Oct. 1 report. He predicted recovering deliveries, low inventories and strong pricing will drive “remarkable near-term earnings momentum” for BMW AG and Daimler, with VW also benefiting. (Updates with auto shares index) Published on ‎16‎ ‎October‎, ‎2020‎ ‎08‎:‎00 Updated on ‎16‎ ‎October‎, ‎2020‎ ‎09‎:‎34 Have a confidential tip for our reporters?
